awd_titl_txt: DETER Research Education and Operations Mission Sustainment
awd_abstract_narration:
The project advances the sophistication, robustness and usefulness of the DETERLab testbed, a key scientific laboratory for cybersecurity research and education.  Advances in the research, educational and operational missions of the testbed directly benefit the hundreds of research projects, and thousands of classroom users currently using DETERLab. All proposed activities directly impact users, enabling them to experiment faster, more easily, with higher fidelity and repeatability, and in more sophisticated environments. The research and development efforts taken together  expand capacity for both the research and education communities and are necessary to meet the growing need for cybersecurity professionals in our country today, and the growing need for repeatability, reproducibility and reuse of testbed experiments.

The project is comprised of 16 tasks across three mission objectives to (1) advance  DETERLab's research mission  - these include operationalization of new experimental capabilities, and addition of new tools for users, to allocate and manage experiments, (2) activities that  advance DETERLab's education mission  - these include creation of containerized versions of existing exercises, creation of new shared materials from various sources within and outside of DETERLab, and customization of lab exercises for each student, to prevent cheating, (3) activities that advance DETERLab's operational mission  - these activities improve DETERLab's security, streamline experiment allocation and management, and allow for fast and automated handling of many errors. Many of the planned activities already have 1st generation prototypes, that are  improved, generalized and operationalized under the project. All the source and binary code developed under this proposal is released publicly. All experimental and educational materials are released via DETERLab's sharing portal.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

por.por_cntn:
This project worked to advance research, educational and operational mission of DeterLab through a set of 16 interrelated activities. 

*Intellectual merit*

We have advanced our *research* mission by adding new experimentation capabilities, which allow users to use domain-speciﬁc components for high-ﬁdelity experimentation in network impairments, Internet-scale emulation and wireless emulation, to emulate the role of human factor in cybersecurity experiments and to analyze binary code. We have also provided a catalog of experimental tools.

Our domain-specific components for network emulation allow users to describe network structures or topologies that represent a portion of an overall network, without needing that network to be instantiated on a set of physical or virtual machines.  The technology itself provides high fidelity emulation, ensuring packets transit through the emulated network with the expected network level effects, e.g. bandwidth and latency.  The structures and orchestrating of the network can be stored, enabling sharing between experimenters or reproducibility of past experiments.

Our emulation of human factor in cyberexperiements leverages a cognitive agent simulation using models drawn from experimental work that respond plausibly to the conditions of the network experiment. We leveraged our existing open-source agent modeling platform DASH, and integrated these models with the testbed experiments. DASH provides support for several key aspects of agents that can respond to their environment and incorporate a number of human traits, including reactive planning, spreading activation for shift of attention, mental models and a dual-process model of reasoning. DASH agents were integrated with testbed experiments by allowing them to generate real e-mail and vulnerability scanning traffic, which flowed over the experimental network. This way, DASH agents become integral parts of DeterLab experiments, and can be used to emulate human behavior in experiments. 

Our binary analysis platform is hosted at https://binary.deterlab.net, and supports the same login process as DeterLab testbed. The platform allows users to upload binary files, and then explore various analyses we provide. No prior experience with binary analysis, nor software installation is required. Currently, our platform provides several useful services including: visualization of function-call graphs and control-flow graphs, debug symbol extraction, and backward slice data-dependency track. 

 

We leverage angr and Neo4j with Ruby on Rails to build our online binary visualization tool. The construction of function-call graphs, control-flow graphs, and data-dependency track are all completed with angr. After performing all the required analysis, we store the data into Neo4j Graph Database. Finally, we choose to use Ruby on Rails, a web-application framework, as a web server to host our services. 

Another analysis service we provide is the debug symbol extraction. When a source code is compiled to the executable program or a binary, adding debug information helps analyzers to understand the program at the binary level. At the binary visualization project, we make a platform for reverse engineers to map binary to source code level using debug information in ELF binaries, in the section called DWARF. We automate some manual analysis tasks in DWARF analysis to display local variables? types and return values of functions in our platform. 

We have advanced our *educational* mission by adding more education materials to our shared repository. These materials cover more diverse topics in cybersecurity, and also have different complexity, allowing for scaffolding. We have added six new exercises, covering topics of internetworking, IPSec tunnels, low-rate distributed denial-of-service attacks, and binary program analysis.
We have advanced our *operational* mission by improving security and robustness of DeterLab's code, by improving user error messages and by automating detection of critical issues on the testbed and generating email alerts. We have analyzed the entire DeterLab's code base and located and patched multiple vulnerabilities. Our user message improvements have added instructions to users how to self-rectify the problems they are facing, which has significantly reduced the number of new tickets on the testbed. We have written a custom software module to detect critical failures of the testbed, which manifest themselves in multiple projects being unable to allocate experiments in a short time period. The module monitors attempted experiment allocations and their outcomes and detects when conditions may signal a critical failure. It then generates an alert email to testbed operations team.

 

*Broader impacts*

This project has impacted researchers and students that currently use DeterLab. There are approximately 2,000 users per semester, out of which approximately 1,300 are students enrolled into cybersecurity classes, which use DeterLab. Our activities have provided more repeatable, reusable and robust experimentation capabilities to research users. They have also enable new ways to experiment in domains of binary analysis, human factors in cybersecurity, Internet-scale emulation, wireless emulation and connectivity impairments. Our education materials rovided more diverse and gradated set of hands-on exercises to students, thus contributing to development of cybersecurity workforce. Our innovations in testbed operations improved robustness and usability of DeterLab testbed.


Last Modified: 12/29/2021
Modified by: Jelena Mirkovic

Images (1 of )
  • Binary visualization of a small executable. The left pane shows control-flow graph, and the right pane shows DWARF information for different functions in the binary.
    DREAM project
    Creative Commons
    Jelena Mirkovic
    Binary visualization
  • DASH key classes and their APIs. For DREAMS effort we have extended mailSender.py, attacker.py and phish_experiment.py files
    DREAM project
    Creative Commons
    Jelena Mirkovic
    DASH architecture
  • Sample topology emulated on Click router, along with bandwidth and delay constraints
    DREAM project
    Creative Commons
    Jelena Mirkovic
    Domain-specific components
